IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAA 8648 S1381-1169(13)00038-1 10.1016/j.molcata.2013.01.025 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 XRD patterns for catalysts: (a) fresh Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3, (b) used Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3, (c) fresh MgFe0.1Al1.9O4, and (d) used MgFe0.1Al1.9O4. Fig. 2 H2-TPR profiles of catalysts: (a) Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3 and (b) MgFe0.1Al1.9O4. Fig. 3 57Fe Mössbauer spectra of MgO-Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3: (a) fresh Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3, (b) Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3-450, and (c) Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3-650. Fig. 4 EB conversion as a function of time on stream over:(a) fresh Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3, (b) Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3-450, and (c) Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3-650. Fig. 5 57Fe Mössbauer spectra of MgFe0.1Al1.9O4: (a) fresh MgFe0.1Al1.9O4, (b) MgFe0.1Al1.9O4-450, and (c) MgFe0.1Al1.9O4-650. Fig. 6 EB conversion as a function of time on stream over MgFe0.1Al1.9O4: (a) fresh MgFe0.1Al1.9O4, (b) MgFe0.1Al1.9O4-450, and (c) MgFe0.1Al1.9O4-650. Fig. 7 Schematic representation of the mechanistic model of EB dehydrogenation with CO2 over Fe-doped MgAl2O4 spinel. Fig. 8 57Fe Mössbauer spectra of used catalysts: (a) used MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 for 8h and (b) used MgFe0.1Al1.9O4-650 for 8h. Table 1 BET surface area of the catalysts and their catalytic activity at 1h and 8h. Catalysts BET surface area (m2/g) EB conversion (%) Styrene selectivity (%) TOF a (h−1) Fresh Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3 181 13.0 91.2 6.4 Used Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3 154 13.5 93.7 6.7 Fresh MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 102 27.5 92.3 16.0 Used MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 95 26.9 97.6 15.6 a Turnover frequency (TOF) were calculated based on hydrogen chemisorption. Sample IS (mm/s) QS (mm/s) H (T) LW (mm/s) Area (%) Remarks Used MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 after 8h 0.29 0.80 0.58 78.6 Fe3+ in Oh 0.59 1.64 0.58 11.2 Fe2+ in Td 0.70 2.43 0.58 10.2 Fe2+ in FeAl2O4 Used MgFe0.1Al1.9O4-650 after 8h 0.29 0.80 0.58 69.9 Fe3+ in Oh 0.59 1.64 0.58 12.0 Fe2+ in Td 0.70 2.43 0.58 18.1 Fe2+ in FeAl2O4 Ethylbenzene dehydrogenation with CO2 over Fe-doped MgAl2O4 spinel catalysts: Synergy effect between Fe2+ and Fe3+ Min Ji a ⁎ Xiaoyan Zhang a Junhu Wang b Sang-Eon Park c a School of Chemistry, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116023, China b Mössbauer Effect Data Center, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, PR China c Laboratory of Nano-Green Catalysis and Nano Center for Fine Chemicals Fusion Technology, Department of Chemistry, Inha University, Incheon 402-751, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 411 84986329; fax: +86 411 84986329. Graphical abstract Highlights ► The catalysts were studied by Mössbauer spectroscopy combining with the partial reduction method. ► The synergy effect between Fe2+ and Fe3+ contributed to the good catalytic performance. ► A possible mechanism of EB dehydrogenation with CO2 over Fe-doped spinel was proposed. Fe-doped MgAl2O4 spinel catalyst of MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 and supported catalyst of Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3 for ethylbenzene dehydrogenation in the presence of CO2 were studied by Mössbauer spectroscopy (MS) combining with the partial reduction method in the presence of H2, and the catalytic activity of the ferrous iron species was discussed. The results showed that the catalytic performance of Fe3+ existing in spinel is superior to α-Fe2O3, and the synergistic effect between Fe2+ and Fe3+ might indeed increase the catalytic activity since Fe2+–O2− formed in the process of reduction has moderate basicity, which was more favorable for desorption of CO2 compared with Mg2+–O2−. The reduced MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 containing Fe2+ of around 25% exhibits much higher catalytic activity than unreduced catalyst, with improved styrene yield nearly 2 times to 45.0%. Mg x Fe1−x O as another ferrous iron species formed in the reduction process of Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3 showed inconspicuously catalytic activity. Keywords Ethylbenzene dehydrogenation Spinel 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy Synergy 1 Introduction Styrene is one of the most important basic chemicals as a monomer of polymers and it is industrially produced by the dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene (EB) over promoted iron oxide catalysts in the presence of a large quantity of steam at high temperature of 600–700°C [1]. However, steam is used excessively with respect to EB (steam/EB=6–13mol/mol) that the amount of energy spent is very high (1.5×106 kcal/styrene ton) [2]. Currently, dehydrogenation of EB in the presence of CO2 (reaction I) has been extensively investigated because of its well-documented advantages over the steam-based process, such as energy-saving, alleviating thermodynamic equilibrium limitations (1.9×105 kcal/styrene ton) [2], suppressing the total oxidation, reducing carbon deposit on the catalyst surface, and so on. Simultaneously, the process can mitigate concerns about the problem of greenhouse effect, and provide both environmental and economical benefits. (I) C6H5CH2 CH3 +CO2 →C6H5CHCH2 +CO+H2O A lot of reports are available on EB dehydrogenation reaction in the presence of CO2 over a variety of catalysts, such as iron oxide [3], vanadium oxide [4,5], TiO2–ZrO2 mixed oxide [6,7], hydrotalcite-like oxide [8,9], spinel oxide [10–13], and Fe-containing ceramic composites [14]. Among these, spinel oxides containing iron species as catalysts for EB dehydrogenation have been screened extensively due to the benefits in preventing the deactivation process and increasing the activity of dehydrogenation of EB in the presence of CO2. The active state of the iron-based catalyst under reaction conditions attracted the attention of many researchers. Many reporters think that Fe3+ species is the active phase for EB dehydrogenation with CO2, and Fe2+ and other reduction states of iron decrease the catalytic activity. Ranke [15] reported that unpromoted Fe2O3 was much more active than Fe3O4 and that KFeO2 was the active species for K-promoted iron oxide catalyst in the dehydrogenation of EB. KFeO2 as the active phase was also identified by Lundin et al. [16] and Coulter et al. [17]. Zhu et al. [18] found that an initial high activity was correlated with Fe3+, and Ramos et al. [19] also thought that Fe3+ species was active phase. Marques et al. [20] reported that the deactivation mechanism was that by-products of the dehydrogenation (hydrogen, carbon monoxide and so on) reduce active species to inactive species that adhered to the catalyst. On the other hand, the positive effects of ferrous iron species for this reaction are also proposed. Lee [21] observed that Fe3O4 (magnetite) was more selective than α-Fe2O3 (hematite). Courty and Le Page [22] mentioned that Fe3O4 was more stable than Fe2O3 after the first 200h operation. Yang et al. [23] suggested that the active site was promoted by a rapid electron exchange between Fe2+ and Fe3+ catalyzed by K. Previously, we demonstrated that MgFe0.1Al1.9O4, which mainly contained Fe3+ in spinel framework, showed excellent activity and good stability for EB dehydrogenation with CO2 [13], but the catalytic activity of other reduction states of iron such as Fe2+, was unclear. In continuation of this study, herein, we wish to disclose the catalytic activity of iron with different chemical valence in Fe-substituted spinel oxides for EB dehydrogenation with CO2. The Fe species of MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 and its reduction states produced at 450°C and 650°C under 5% H2 atmosphere were characterized and related with their catalytic performance. The catalyst of Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3 containing the same element molar ratio with MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 was studied for comparison. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All chemicals were reagent grade and used as supplied. All metal nitrates were hydrate forms. The material inputting molar ratio of the catalysts was same, which was Mg:Al:Fe=1:1.9:0.1. MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 was prepared by sol–gel method [13]: 27.85g of a mixture of magnesium nitrate, aluminum nitrate and iron nitrate were dissolved in 20mL distilled water, followed by adding another solution of 5.80g citric acid in 30mL distilled waster. The mixture was stirred at 80°C until the gelation occurred, then dried at 120°C for 10h. The solid was calcined in an air flow at 700°C for 4h. Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3 was prepared by impregnation method: 8.19g of a mixture of magnesium nitrate and iron nitrate at a molar ratio of 1:0.1 were dissolved in distilled water, in which γ-Al2O3 (Dalian Haixin Chemical Industrial Co., Ltd., 0.425–0.90mm) was added and dipped for 12h. The resulting solids were dried at 120°C and then calcined at 700°C for 4h. The catalysts were reduced in reactor at 450°C and 650°C for 90min at the presence of 5%H2/N2 mixture before reaction, which were labeled as Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3-450, Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3-650, MgFe0.1Al1.9O4-450, MgFe0.1Al1.9O4-650, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The BET surface areas of the catalysts were measured by nitrogen physisorption at −196°C with a surface area analyzer, Micromeritics ASAP 2000. The samples were treated at 350°C in vacuum for 3h before N2 physisorption measurements. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) experiments were carried out on a D/Max 2400 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5418Å) at 40kV and 100mA. The experiments were performed at high diffractions angles (from 20° to 80°). The 57Fe Mössbauer spectra (57Fe MS) were measured by a Topologic MFD-500A Mössbauer spectrometer at room temperature, a 57Co source in rhodium matrix was used. The Doppler velocity of the spectrometer was calibrated with respect to α-Fe foils. The spectra were fitted with superpositions of Lorentzian lines using the MossWinn 3.0i program. Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were carried out on Chem BET Pulsar TPR/TPD. Each sample (0.1g) was pretreated at 600°C for 30min in helium flow of 100ml/min. After cooling to 100°C, TPR experiments were performed in H2 flow at a heating rate of 10°C/min. The sample was heated from 100 to 900°C and kept at 900°C for 30min until the signal was invariable. 2.3 Catalytic tests The catalysts were evaluated in the dehydrogenation of EB in the presence of carbon dioxide at 600°C under atmospheric pressure. The reaction was carried out in a fixed-bed tubular stainless steel reactor where 0.6g catalyst was placed. Previously, the samples were activated in situ under a nitrogen flow from room temperature to 600°C over the course of 90min to purge all gaseous impurities from the catalyst surface. The reaction was started by introducing a gas mixture of EB and carbon dioxide with a molar ratio of 1:5 to the reactor. The flows used were N2: 30.40mmol/h; CO2: 49.15mmol/h; EB: 9.83mmol/h. Every 1h, the products were analyzed by gas chromatography on Agilent-6890 equipped with a FID detector and capillary column of HP-5. The catalytic performance was evaluated in terms of the conversion of EB and the selectivity for styrene production. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization and catalytic activity of catalysts Table 1 presents the surface areas, EB conversion and styrene selectivity of the fresh catalysts and used catalysts after 8h. Though fresh Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3 had higher surface areas of 181m2/g, it decreased apparently to 154m2/g after 8h reactions. Whereas little decrease of surface areas was found in MgFe0.1Al1.9O4, which implies that MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 is an anti-sintering catalyst. On the other hand, it was clearly seen that MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 exhibited much higher EB conversion than Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3. At 8h, EB convention over MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 was 26.9%, twice as much as that of 13.5% over Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3. And styrene selectivity was 97.6% over MgFe0.1Al1.9O4, which was also higher than that over Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3 (93.7%). It is noteworthy that MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 has identical compositions and lower surface area compared with Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3 (Table 1), but it showed better catalytic activity. Consequently, we proposed that the preparation methods had a great influence on the catalytic performance of iron oxide-based catalysts. The XRD patterns of the fresh and used catalysts (after 8h reaction) are displayed in Fig. 1 . The result showed that the peak intensities of MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 were sharp and all diffraction lines could be unequivocally assigned to a spinel-type structure with a space group of Fd3m. The lattice parameter of fresh MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 (8.101Å) is a bit more than fresh MgAl2O4 (8.088Å) by the calculation of MDI jade 5.0. As a result of the radius of Fe3+ (0.064nm) and Fe2+ (0.074nm) are larger than that of Al3+ (0.050nm) and Mg2+ (0.065nm), the lattice parameters of MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 will increase when iron ions substitute for Al3+ or Mg2+ in the MgAl2O4 spinel lattice. The XRD patterns of MgO–Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 showed characteristic peaks of spinel, but its intensity of reflections were weaken and broaden that expressed its low crystallinity. The peaks at 2θ =42.8° and 62.3° were assigned to MgO, but no bulk crystal phase of α-Fe2O3 can be observed, which indicated that Fe species had formed spinel on the surface of γ-Al2O3 with MgO or highly dispersed in the catalyst surface. After the reaction of 8h, there was no obvious change of spinel characteristic peaks in XRD pattern, which suggested that the structure of the catalysts was stable. The TPR profiles of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . Three main reduction peaks at 453°C, 564°C and 703°C in the TPR profiles of Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3 were observed. The peaks at 453°C and 564°C are assigned to the reduction process of Fe2O3 →Fe3O4 →FeO [24,25]. However, FeO is so labile that it can easily react with MgO to form stable Mg1−x Fe x O [24]. The peak at 703°C is ascribed to the reduction of Fe3+ in spinel lattice and the further reduction of Fe2+ to metallic Fe. The small peak at about 418°C in TPR curve of MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 indicated that the isolated α-Fe2O3 was reduced to Fe2+ species [12]. The broad peak at about 858°C corresponded to the hard reduction of Fe3+ that incorporated into MgAl2O4 to Fe2+ and further to Fe0 [24]. The temperature of the last peak of MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 was higher than that of Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3 (703°C), indicating that the spinel structure formed in MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 was more stable, which was accord with the result of XRD. Based on the result of BET, XRD and H2-TPR, the good catalytic performance of MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 may be due to its intact spinel structure and large mount of Fe species that have incorporated into spinel structure. 3.2 Discussion of the catalytic activity of Fe2+ In order to elucidate the catalytic activity of ferrous iron species, the catalysts was reduced at 5% H2/N2 atmosphere at 450°C and 650°C for 90min, respectively, based on the results of H2-TPR. The Mössbauer spectra were analyzed to understand the coordinated environment and valence state of iron species of catalysts, and the results were related to their catalytic performances. Fig. 3 shows the 57Fe Mössbauer spectra of fresh and reduced Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3. The associated data are listed in Table 2 . The 57Fe Mössbauer spectra of fresh Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3 were fitted with a sextuplet and two doublet peaks. The sextuplet peak with magnetic field (H) of 51.32T and an isomer shift (IS) of 0.35mm/s was characteristic of α-Fe2O3 with large particle size [13]. The doublet with an IS of 0.28mm/s and a QS of 0.76mm/s was assigned to Fe3+ in octahedral site of spinel (75.4%), and the other doublet with an IS of 0.59mm/s was ascribed to Fe2+ in tetrahedral site of spinel (4.2%). After reduction at 450°C for 90min, α-Fe2O3 disappeared while two new doublets were observed, one with isomer shift of 0.49mm/s assigned to Mg1−x Fe x O [24,26,27], which was formed in the reaction of FeO and MgO. The other characterized with isomer shift of 0.64mm/s was assigned to Fe2+ in FeAl2O4, which was formed in the interfaces between FeO and γ-Al2O3 [28]. Same kind of species were also found in Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3-650, α-Fe2O3 disappeared and the content of Fe3+ in octahedral site of spinel decreased, and the doublets of Fe2+ in FeAl2O4 and Mg1−x Fe x O were also observed. But different from Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3-450, the content of Mg1−x Fe x O in Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3-650 decreased from 30.6% to 5.5% and the content of Fe2+ in Td increased from 2.8% to 27.9%, which might be related to the formation of Mg1−x Fe x Al2O4 from the reaction of Mg1−x Fe x O with γ-Al2O3 at 650°C [29]. The changes in trend of EB conversion with reaction time on stream over Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3, Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3-450 and Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3-650 are displayed in Fig. 4 . It was observed that the catalytic performance of Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3-450 was better than the fresh catalyst, which indicated that the new species, maybe Fe2+ in FeAl2O4 or Mg x Fe1−x O, was conducive to enhance the catalytic activity. Furthermore, the conversion of EB (26.6%) was highest in the first hour over Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3-650, up to 2 times of fresh catalyst. One possible reason is that Fe2+ emerged from the reduction of both α-Fe2O3 and Fe3+ in spinel was beneficial to catalytic performance. Based on the analysis of MS, as well as the result of catalytic activity of the reduced catalysts, we propose that the higher catalytic performance of Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3-650 can be due to the existence of Fe2+ in A site of the spinel, including Fe2+ in FeAl2O4 and Fe2+ in Td, which has promotional effect on catalytic activity, while Mg x Fe1−x O can hardly contribute to catalytic activity. The 57Fe Mössbauer spectra and its fitting data of fresh and reduced MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 are exhibited in Fig. 5 and Table 3 , respectively. Fresh MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 displayed two doublets: an IS of 0.28mm/s and a QS of 0.82mm/s was assigned to Fe3+ in octahedral site of spinel with content of 89.6%; the other with an IS of 0.59mm/s was Fe2+ in tetrahedral with content of 10.4%. There is no peak that could be assigned to α-Fe2O3 in MgFe0.1Al1.9O4, which also demonstrated that most iron species had incorporated into the spinel lattice. After reduction at 450°C, no new iron species was found, but Fe2+ in tetrahedral site of spinel increased to 14.8%. Moreover, the small amount of α-Fe2O3 in MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 was theoretically reduced at 450°C as can be seen from the results of H2-TPR. However, the result was not observed from 57Fe Mössbauer spectrometer due to the trace of α-Fe2O3. After reduction at 650°C, the content of Fe2+ in FeAl2O4 and tetrahedral site increased to 13.0% and 12.0%, respectively. Fig. 6 shows the change in trend of EB conversion with reaction time on stream over fresh MgFe0.1Al1.9O4, MgFe0.1Al1.9O4-450 and MgFe0.1Al1.9O4-650. Same results were also found that reduced catalyst showed higher EB conversion compared with the fresh catalyst, which indicated that Fe2+ in spinel could contribute to better catalytic performance. Based on aforementioned results of XRD, 57Fe Mössbauer and catalytic activity, it is herein proposed that the Fe3+ in B site of spinel is probably the active species and Fe2+ in A site of spinel has a promoting effect on catalytic activity. In EB dehydrogenation over iron-based oxides catalysts, Miura et al. [30] considered the formation of π-adsorbed intermediate on Fe3+ acid centers, which dissociates the α-hydrogen reversibly as a proton on a basic site, based on H-D exchange study. A similar mechanism was also reported by Tope et al. [31]: H+ abstracted on Mg2+–O2− basic sites, followed by further dehydrogenation to styrene via the reduction of Fe3+ to Fe2+. Styrene and H2 were simultaneously desorbed with the reoxidation of Fe2+ to Fe3+. However, Mg2+–O2− has low capacity for adsorption of CO2 because of the strongly basic sites [12], which results in low rate of dehydrogenation. Fe2+–O2− formed in the process of reduction has moderate basicity [12], which was more favorable for desorption of CO2. The base sites, e.g., oxygen species and O− species activate the gaseous CO2 to form an O− entity, which abstracts the β-hydrogen [32]. The reaction of EB with CO2 has been shown to occur on O− species [33]. Based on the above results, we proposed the mechanism of EB dehydrogenation with CO2 over Fe-doped MgAl2O4 spinel catalyst as shown in Fig. 7 . According to the mechanism, we can forecast that small portion of Fe3+ would be reduced by CO that generated in the reaction while the catalytic activity will not decrease. On the other hand, too much active species of Fe3+ reduced to Fe2+ would also weaken the catalytic activity. This point can be supported by results of the 57Fe Mössbauer spectra of used MgFe0.1Al1.9O4-650 and used MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 as shown in Fig. 8 and Table 4 . After reaction, the content of Fe3+ decreased while the content of Fe2+ increased, indicating that partial Fe3+ was reduced by by-products of the dehydrogenation (hydrogen, carbon monoxide and so on) during the reaction [34], which was also found in our previous work [13]. In spent catalyst without firstly reduction, the content of Fe2+ was increased from 10.4% to 21.4%, but EB conversion was almost invariant, from initial conversion of 27.5% to 26.9% after 8h. So we think that proper level of Fe2+ is favorable for catalytic activity, and it neutralized the decrease of catalytic activity caused by deposited coke and poisoning of the catalysts. The content of Fe2+ in MgFe0.1Al1.9O4-650 was 25.0% (Table 4), but after reaction its content was 30.1%. However, MgFe0.1Al1.9O4-650 showed poorly catalytic stability, from initial conversion of 49.4% to 33.8% after 8h, which agrees well with the forecast. 4 Conclusions The structure of the catalysts is an important influence to its catalytic activity. MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 with good spinel structure shows high activity; Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3 with large particle size of α-Fe2O3 and low spinel crystallinity shows relatively low catalytic activity, which reveals that Fe3+ in spinel is more active than α-Fe2O3. Fe2+–O2− formed in the reduction process of the catalysts possesses moderate basicity, which is more favorable for desorption of CO2 compared with Mg2+–O2−. Synergy effect between Fe2+ and Fe3+ is beneficial to increase the catalytic activity of the iron-based catalyst for the EB dehydrogenation reaction with CO2. However, excessive Fe2+ substitutes the active sites of Fe3+ will weaken the catalytic activity. The results suggest that MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 contains about 25% of Fe2+ of shows best catalytic activity, improves styrene yield nearly 2 times to 45.0%. coredata.dc:description: Fe-doped MgAl2O4 spinel catalyst of MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 and supported catalyst of Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3 for ethylbenzene dehydrogenation in the presence of CO2 were studied by Mössbauer spectroscopy (MS) combining with the partial reduction method in the presence of H2, and the catalytic activity of the ferrous iron species was discussed. The results showed that the catalytic performance of Fe3+ existing in spinel is superior to α-Fe2O3, and the synergistic effect between Fe2+ and Fe3+ might indeed increase the catalytic activity since Fe2+–O2− formed in the process of reduction has moderate basicity, which was more favorable for desorption of CO2 compared with Mg2+–O2−. The reduced MgFe0.1Al1.9O4 containing Fe2+ of around 25% exhibits much higher catalytic activity than unreduced catalyst, with improved styrene yield nearly 2 times to 45.0%. Mg x Fe1−x O as another ferrous iron species formed in the reduction process of Fe2O3–MgO/γ-Al2O3 showed inconspicuously catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Ethylbenzene dehydrogenation with CO2 over Fe-doped MgAl2O4 spinel catalysts: Synergy effect between Fe2+ and Fe3+
